summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from Christopher Dilorio, a self-identified whistleblower, to various government and media recipients. The emails allege widespread financial crimes, including money laundering, securities fraud, and corrupt connections between private equity firms (notably Apollo Global Management), Jeffrey Epstein, Jared Kushner, and Russian interests. Dilorio accuses the SEC and other agencies of gross corruption and cover-ups.

persons.name: Christopher Dilorio
persons.context: Self-identified whistleblower sending a series of emails alleging massive financial fraud, money laundering, and corruption involving Apollo Global Management, Jeffrey Epstein, Jared Kushner, and others. He accuses the SEC of being a corrupt criminal organization.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as a pedophile and a key figure in alleged financial fraud and money laundering schemes. The email claims his only SEC filing was connected to Leon Black's Apollo and a company called Environmental Solutions Worldwide.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Described as a 'Milken degenerate' and protege. Allegedly connected to Epstein, Kushner, and Russian interests (Putin). Implicated in money laundering shells and financial fraud.

persons.name: Jared Kushner
persons.role: Senior White House Advisor / Real Estate Executive
persons.context: Alleged to have financial ties to Apollo Global Management, including a loan for 666 Fifth Avenue. Emails suggest Apollo dropped an SEC investigation after Kushner met with Apollo's Joshua Harris and Apollo provided financing.

persons.name: Joshua Harris
persons.context: A founding partner of Apollo. Email alleges he was considered for a White House job and that Apollo's SEC investigation was dropped after a meeting with Kushner.

persons.name: Nathan Milikowsky
persons.context: Led the 'Save GrafTech' investor group. Mentioned in context of SEC filings and an Haaretz article about FBI possibly probing his ties to Netanyahu.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Described as a 'Bag Man' and linked to investment in CollPlant and money laundering through Balmore/Alpha Capital.

persons.name: Stephen M. Calk
persons.context: Former bank CEO charged with corruptly soliciting a presidential administration position in exchange for approving loans. Linked to Lorber and Elliman in the email narrative.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Named as the attorney announcing charges against Stephen Calk. Addressed in the email as 'Ms Strauss'.

persons.name: William F. Sweeney Jr
persons.role: FBI Assistant Director-in-Charge, NY Field Office
persons.context: Named alongside Audrey Strauss in the announcement of charges against Stephen Calk.

persons.name: Patricia Tarasca
persons.context: Named alongside Audrey Strauss in the announcement of charges against Stephen Calk.

persons.name: Phillip Frost
persons.context: Charged by the SEC in pump-and-dump schemes. Linked to money laundering through Alpha Capital Anstalt and Ladenburg Thalmann.

persons.name: Stephen Feinberg
persons.context: Chosen by Trump to lead an intelligence advisory panel. Described as 'Scum of the Earth' and linked to money laundering bank HSH and Georgios Ekonomou.

persons.name: George Economou
persons.context: Also referred to as Georgios Ekonomou. CEO of DryShips. Allegedly involved in money laundering shells and connected to Marc Bistricer, AQR, and Kushner.

persons.name: Marc Bistricer
persons.context: Toronto-based investment manager linked to George Economou's DryShips and Clipper Realty. Implied to be part of money laundering networks.

persons.name: Andrew Ekonomou
persons.role: Attorney / Member of Trump's Legal Team
persons.context: An obscure medieval historian turned attorney who was part of Trump's legal team for the Russia investigation. Noted as a possible relative of George Economou.

persons.name: Stephanie Avakian
persons.context: Named in the context of alleged 'home cooking' and the SEC dropping an investigation into Apollo after Kushner met with Apollo's Joshua Harris.

persons.name: Robert Mueller III
persons.role: Former FBI Director / Partner at WilmerHale
persons.context: Mentioned in a link about him joining WilmerHale law firm, which is connected to other figures in the email chain like Jamie Gorelick.

persons.name: Jamie Gorelick
persons.context: A well-known Washington litigator at WilmerHale, a firm linked in the email to the Apollo/Kushner narrative.

persons.name: Mark Yung
persons.context: Listed on the board of ESW Group (Environmental Solutions Worldwide), a company central to the alleged money laundering scheme.

persons.name: Vladimir Putin
persons.context: Allegedly connected to Leon Black/Apollo/Schwarzman through a Russian investment fund. The email claims Black 'shares platform with Putin.'

connections.description: Alleged financial and social connections. Email claims Epstein's only SEC filing was connected to Black's Apollo and a company they were both involved with (Environmental Solutions Worldwide).
Alleged financial ties, including Apollo funding Kushner's 666 Fifth Avenue redevelopment. Email suggests Apollo dropped an SEC probe after Kushner met with Apollo's Joshua Harris.
Alleged quid pro quo: SEC dropped investigation into Apollo after Kushner met with Apollo's Joshua Harris and Apollo gave Kushner's company a loan.
Email claims Epstein's Financial Trust Company Inc.'s only SEC filing was related to this company, implicating it in alleged money laundering.
Email links Black/Apollo to Putin/Russia through a Russian sovereign wealth fund, claiming Black 'shares platform with Putin.'
Linked through the DryShips investment and alleged money laundering shell activities. Both have Toronto connections.
Calk charged with corruptly soliciting a position in the Trump administration in exchange for loans.
Linked to money laundering through the Liechtenstein-based entity Alpha Capital Anstalt, as alleged in Dilorio's 2013 TCR.

events.title: NYT Article on Epstein's Finances
events.description: New York Times article published questioning Jeffrey Epstein's claimed wealth, suggesting his 'infinite means' may be a mirage and that he got rich with the help of two wealthy connections.

events.title: Charges Against Bank CEO Stephen Calk
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY (Audrey Strauss) announces charges against bank CEO Stephen M. Calk for corruptly soliciting a presidential administration position in exchange for approving $16 million in loans.

events.title: SEC Drops Apollo Investigation
events.description: Alleged event where the SEC dropped an investigation into Apollo Global Management a month after the firm gave Jared Kushner's family business a $180 million loan. Reported by NY Post in March 2018.

events.title: Apollo's Massive Inflows
events.description: Apollo Global Management reports over $60 billion in inflows during 2018, following the alleged dropped investigation and Kushner dealings.

events.title: Apollo-Citigroup Loan to Kushner Companies
events.description: CNBC reports that Apollo and Citigroup loaned Kushner Companies millions, and that Kushner discussed a White House job for Apollo founder Joshua Harris.

events.title: Brookfield/Apollo 666 Fifth Ave Financing
events.description: Report that Brookfield Property Partners turned to Apollo Global Management for a $300M+ mezzanine loan to redevelop 666 Fifth Avenue, a property owned by Kushner Companies.

keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges a vast network of money laundering and securities fraud connecting Apollo Global Management (Leon Black, Joshua Harris), Jeffrey Epstein, Jared Kushner, and Russian interests.

Dilorio claims the SEC is a 'grossly corrupt criminal organization' that actively covers up these crimes and intimidates whistleblowers, citing a dropped investigation into Apollo after it loaned money to Kushner's company.

A key allegation is that Jeffrey Epstein's only SEC filing was connected to Leon Black's Apollo and a penny stock company, Environmental Solutions Worldwide (ESWW), which is presented as a money laundering shell.

The emails draw connections between numerous figures and entities, including Greek shipping magnate George Economou, Toronto investor Marc Bistricer, charged banker Stephen Calk, and Liechtenstein-based Alpha Capital Anstalt, painting a picture of a global financial conspiracy.
Dilorio references his own past TCRs (Tip, Complaint or Referrals) filed with the SEC as containing evidence of these schemes, which he claims the agency has ignored.
